div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,239] ALEXANDRIA, Wednesday, FEBRUARY 14, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Important Announcement
div.p: Steam Ploughing,Cultivating,Levelling and Grading. Messrs, J. & H. MoLAREN, Manufncturera of Steam Ploughing Machinery, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, now beg to announce to their friends in Egypt, that Mr. Henry McLaren, one of their principe a, will he in Egypt for the month of March, 1906- He will be glad to make appointments with any interested parties to show them our steam plough tackle at work in Egypt, and will visit and inspect any lands on which it may be intended to work steam plough?, and give most favourable prices for suitable Machinery. He vill show them our new Pa iert Gasobeah, or b veiling rcoop, at work, which is the most improved method of handling Urge quantities of sand or soil for levelling purposes which has y. t been pui upon the mark. t. Land»d Proprietors, Agriculturists, and Contractors, are requested to com* municate with Mr. MoLAREN at tthepheard's Hotel, Cbiio, after March let, 1906.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: Yesterday opened with a light breeze from the N.N.E. but towards noon the wind suddenly changed to the N.N.W. The day was rather warm, but becme beautifully cool in the evening. Barometer steady.

div.head: THE FRONTIER QUESTION
div.p: The newa that the Akaba frontier qnef tior will in all probability be settled in the cex few days, will be received with general satisfaction, bat in view of the maidents on tb» western and eastern boundaries of Egypt which have ooonrved during the paet eighteen nenthe, it would, ia oar opinion, be well if the Porte and the Khedivial Government fmnd it possible to arrange for the early and thorough delimitation of the land frontiers of Egypt and Tripoli on the one hand and of Egypt and Syria on the other. As long ai theie frontiers remain urrdefinel, there is always a certain risk of what is ejphemistiorily termed 'an incident' oooorring, and happen ng-i of this nature, though regarded at present with a light heart in Alexandria and Cairo, might have a disturbing iufiuenoe in thd future. An finoideut' on any fro itier is in ninety oine oases out of a hundred settled by the good senre of the «fR rials oivil or militvy on each side, and Sinai is at present of interest and importance to none hat arobeeo- logists, and students of the wanderings of the twelve tribes. But when the Akaba and perhaps El Arish and Port Said are linked with Constantinople by a system of military railways, and when the Turkish hand has closed tightly over Syria and Northern Arabia, the ohanoe of unintentional violations of the frontier will iu or ease pari passu with the augmentation of the Ottoman forces in those regions, and the delimitation of the frontier will become absolutely neoessary. 'Incidents' under such oircumstanoes mast oause a certain amount of disquiet and react injuriously on oommeroe and tr^de. Fi- nance is always sensitive to political possibilities and when the Turkish Government be- oomes capable of transporting large foroes by rail to Syria and N. Arabia, where six divisions —seme ninety thousand men —oan already be mobilised, the slightest inoident, aud much more an accidental collision—always poasib'e on an ill-defined frontier—might oause considerable alarm in Egypt. The relations of the Khedivial Government with its Suzerain are excellent, and the British Government, which is deeply interested in the fature of Egypt and the Sudan, has always shown itself amiosbly disposed towards the Porte on all Egyptian questions. But whatever the relations between the above-mentioned Statee, no amount of friendliness between Governments need ever prevent their obtaining guarantees against future difficulties. We write under correction, but it seems to ns that a delimitation of the frontiers between Tarkey and Egypt is neoessary, aud that the adoption of this course may save considerable trouble in the fature. Of course it takes two to make a bargain and to mark a boundary, and the Porte m«y, for reasons of its own, be unwilling to despatch a oommission to the Tureo-Bgyptian frontier, but we can see DO reason why the Ottoman Government should refuse to follow a polioy than can do it no injury, and should make the relations between the governments involved even more friendly than before.

Mohamedan Celebration in London.

The annual Service of Atonement, which Corresponds with the conclusion of the pilgrimage to Mecca, was observed by about 60 Mohamedans in London, on the 6th.' inst Ike ceremony took place in a private room at the Uolborn restaurant, and was made to resemble the one at Mecca as nearly as posable. The ro>m was stripped of it* furniture, hi order ihat the worshippers might spread their praytr mats on the floor and prostrate themselves upon th»m with their ftces turned towards Mecca, dll the prayers were in Arabio. io accordance with the Mohamedan custom, the devotions were followed in the evening by feast. This took the form of a dinner called the id al du ha, under the auspices of the Par - Islamic Society. It was served at the Holhorn Restaurant, and was presided over by the I orkish Ambassador. The menu was severely Roglish, and most of the guests were in evenii g druL

div.head: A SUDANESE FOUNDLING.
div.p: A regimental romance attaches to 'he career of John Francis Durham, a membe** of the band of the Durham Light Infantry, who i- now on a v sit to Nottingham with his foster parents. During the Sudanese campaign of 1885 an outpost of the regiment returned the fire of two boatloads of natives proceeding 1 -wn the Ni e at a point about 150 mile" below Khartoum. Such of the natives as were nor killed or wounded swaui to the opposite ride of the river and esoapel, leavirgin ore of the boats a dead native woman, io whose arms was a baby boy some twelve months old. The English (-o'di era nursed and took him to India, where he was adopted by the wife of Sergeant-Major Ficher, herself a Nottingham woman, and he was baptized John Framd- Durham. The little Sudanese made excellent progress at school, and displaying a talent fir mush, he is at the pre ent time one of tb* first olarionets in the Durham'** military band al o playing first violia iu the string band of the regiment.

div.head: NILE-RED SEA RAILWAY
div.p: STRATEGIC ADVANTAGES. INDEPENDENCE OF SUEZ CANAL.

The military value of the line of railway connecting Berber with the Red Sea, a military authority points out, may be secondary to the development of the Sudan provinoe, but it has also great importance. It his its stra-tegic advantages, for it must obviously shorten 'he land route to India, and makes us independent of the Suez Canal should it eyer be blooked at a oruo;al moment, or should any international difficulties arise as to the conveyance of troops along its neutral waters. It implies, of coarse, the free use of the Mediterranean, bat we hardly dare to contemplate its being denied to ns, or that we should surrender it lightly. There are those who argue, not without reason, that our ultimate communication with India is by sea, round the Cape of Good Hope, but time is the essence of the problem, and safety may depend entirely upon the saving of a few weeks. Egypt will be far superior then to South Afrioa as ao advance base, and could be filled with a considerable force ready for prompt reii forcemeat if danger came suddenly on the north-west frontier. When or how soon that may no threatened no one can say, but that it is inevitable in the long ron is firmly believed by experts, Lird Roberts among the number, and on such a scale that not even the loyalty of our Japanese allies, if we oan count upon and choose to accept their assistance, can saffioe for the detenoe of India

div.head: THE CAB STRIKE.
div.p: The cab strike at Akxaadria still continues, much to the dissatinfactioa of the inhabitants, who are immensely inconvenienced.

The Commandant of Police, this morning, advised the strikers to resame work and promised that the new tariff wonld be considered to-day by the Municipal Commission, but the oabmen staunchly refused to follow his advice aud eviuoed a firmer desire to go on with the strike.They hope that by adopting this attitude their demands will be satisfied.

At the Municipal meeting held this morning, the question of the strike was not discassed owing to the non-pessumus attitude of the men. The Commission will not meet again for a month, and the Commandant of Police has a* andoned his pn ject of drawing up a new tariff.

The Parquet summoned a number of oab- m«n, a rested during the past few days, and held an enquiry into the oharges against them. They were chiefly aoonsed of inciting their fellows to strikeout four of them were charged with heating blaoklegs. They were all discharged.

div.head: DJELALEDDIN PACHA.
div.p: It is stated that one of the Khedivial Princes recai t y received private information from Cons a itinopl* to the effeotthat the S iltan had not cot firmed the judgment parsed by the Turkish CouuO'1 of D-soipline on Ferik Ahmed Djelaleddin Pacha. The many friends of the Pacha will be glad to know therefore that his Excellenoy has not been stripped of his honours, or deprived of his estates in Turkey.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: SUEZ, Tue>day.

A few dayi ago, two very audacious robberies took place in Suez and Port Tewfik, and the victim* were two ve y well koown Eng'i-h families. In broad day ighc last Friday, a thief entered a hou e in Suez aud made off with a new overcoat and a very valaable Persian carpet, and subsequently the same man committed a similar robbery at Port Tewfik. Finally, thanks to the moBt energetic steps taken by H.E. the Govaruor of Sues, Ibrahim Bey Helmi, and the ohief of polioe, Mr. De Touris, who took considerable interest in the matter, the robber was caught, and the missing articles, which had been already sold, have been restored intaot to their owners. Both the Governor aqd chief of polioe must be congratulated ou their effort* towards making the police efficient, and all the res dents are very gra'efol .

div.head: KHEDIVIAL OPERA, CAIRO
div.p: PRODUCTION OF "WALLY." SECOND NOVELTY OF THE SEASON.

The sooond novelty of the Cairo season, Catalani's WaUy, was given on Thursday and Saturday night. Composed about 1895 this opera was at first a fiasco. Catalani did not live to see it obtain any sneoess. Bronght on the stage again two years ago, it was receiv ed more favourably and, had the oomposer been present at the last representation of WaUy in Cairo, the enthusiastic approval of tha audience wonld surely have consoled him for the bitter disappointment which he must have felt, when his work was denied its well- deserved merits.
The opera transports ns to the Tyrolese Alps, represented by some good stage soenery, and on Tharsday night by a convkoing blast of cold air from the snow-clad mountains at the back of the stage.
The delightful music, original and exhilarating, qnite suits the place and the plot, an intricate story of love and jealousy between the rivals to the hand of Wally.

The gdJling of the Tyrolese hanters and farmers, the blowing of horns and the ringing of cowbells, the rushing of the molten snow down the slopei of the hills, all the familiar sounds of Tyrolese mountain life,are interwoven with the mnsio.

In the first act, a delioious solo *'Undi verso il Mnrzcll," sang by Walter (Madame Zeppili Alice J, more entioing than ever in a tight- fitting tronbadonr's snit, gives this charming artiste an opportunity to show the capacities of her light soprano to the beet

The act winds up with a passionate love scene, in which Gellner (Mr. Amato Pa-quale) declares his love to Wally, and is rejected by her. Mr. Amato Pasquale's rich amorous baritone salts the melody to perfection.

In proounng as this young artist, who is only 27 years, and has already sang in the principal theatres of Europe, Convent Garden, La Soala, etc., etc., the much-abused 8. A. E. has done something towards deserving the gratitude of the Cairo public.
A special word of praise is also due to Vally (Madame Russ) Giannina, whose voioe showed to admirable effect through a long and difficult rdle.

The orchestral opening of the third not, a oharming bit of music, was encored both evenings. Mr. Paint's rendering of the rdle of Hageubaoh in the fourth act, and especially his solo "M'hai Balvato, hai volnto obliar l'offesa mia," was deserving, and as a whole ihe representation of Wally may be considered as one of the most oreditable performances of the season.

div.head: THE SERATO CONCERT.
div.p: An extremelyinterestingconoertwasgivenon Monday night at the New Khedivial Hotel by the distinguished violinist, Serato, before an audtenoe, whioh, considering the musical opportunity given to the Alexandria public, was a very small one. The performance opened wiih Wieneawski's Concerto with three movements. Of the three the last, the Finale aliaZmgara(or Gypsy) movement, was decidedly the best played and the most enjoyable, being of a light and tuneful character, and at times exhibiting very distinct reminisoenoes of the Bizirria in D major by the same oomposer. The first movement, Allegro Moderate, we thought rather sorappy and dieronsive, and it was not played with qui'e the same oonviotion as the other two. A Beiceau by Jamefeld was au excellent example vf ihe graver and more solemn class of mnsio, which is after all more satisfying than the more difficult bat much less pleasing florid style The simple but impressive harmonies of this latter piece were magnificently rendered, and there, oan be no donbt that in the interpretation of what we may call tha more religious and less purely Whetio' side of musical exaresaion, Signor Serato, in hit sphere, is supreme. Ries' Perpetuem Mobile waa an interesting example of technical skill, and was played with marvel-lous precision and aoonraoy, bat such pieoes unquestionably arouse our wonder without exoiting oar sympathy. Baeh's air on the 4"h string was finely played and Sarasate's Z'gennerweiser, appareut'y another 'Gypsy' theme, was received with immense applause. B it we oannot help thinking that the contrast between the two subjeots of this latter piece was too abrn£t to be entirely satisfactory. The grave opening, 'can Sordino' especially with the exquisite tones that Signor Serato in his pla' ingextraotei from his instrument, left one somewhat unprepared for the extremely light and almost vulgar "dance" subject that followed, expressing less any masioal idea than 1 'he somewhat startling antics of a mountebank. Perhaps the gem of the performer was the "Little Song" by d'Amhrono, given as the first encore i anything more delightful than the quaiut and expressive ending to eaoh variation of the theme as it reourred oan hardly be imagined: it left one in doubt whether to ory or laugh, and stirred up those diBtinot but rather indefinite emotions that ranstitute perhaps the ohief joy is listening to good mnsio.

lt only remains to ton *h briefly unnn the plsyingof Madame MaUtesta. As an aooom- panist she was magnificent, exhibiting all 'hat twt and restraint that are so needful to keep the due relationships bet ween principal and agent dearly defined. Her p'vying of Raohmaninoff's Prelude and Chamidnade's T> ocata showed great technical skill and masio4tseling, and in the latter piece especially, which most be a d'ffioolt one, she received all the applause that her spirited but dignified rendering deserved.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: H. Prince Djemil Paoha Toussoan has returned to Cairo.
Sir Hugh and Lady Alice Shaw Stewart are staying at the British Agenoy.

The Hon. Arthur Stanley, who was for foar years third secretary at the British Agenoy Cairo, is staying at the Savoy Hotel. Mr. Stanley is the third son of the 16th Bari of Derby and represented the Ormskirk division of South-West Lancashire in the late Parliament. in the Conservative interests. He was private secretary to Mr. Balfonr in 1892, and has also been attach^ in the Diplomatic Servioe and olerk in the Foreign Office. He is a keen sportsman and both shoots and plays orioket exceptionally well.
The Abyssinian General Mashasha arrived at Alexandria from Cairo on Monday and is staying at the Windsor Hotel. He leaves on Friday for Palestine.

The Hon. Sidney Peel, who has but lately arrived at the Savoy, is Direotor of the Trust and Loan Company of Canada, as well as Direotor of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt. Born in 1870 he is tha third son of the first Viscount Peel, who was the fifth son of the Rt. Hon. Sir Robert Peel. The Hon. Sidney Peel was educated at Eton, and from thence passed with a scholarship to New College, Oxford. He became Fellow and Leotnrer at Trinity College, Oxford, in 1894, and in the following year took silk at Linooln's Inn. Between the years 1896- 1899 he acted as secretary to the Royal Commission on Liquor Licensing Laws, and secretary to the President of the Probate Division. He joined the Imperial Yeomanry at the outbreak of the South African war and gained his medal with three clasps. He became captain of the Bedfordshire Imperial Yeomanry in 1902, and WAS promoted to major in the following year. He has written various books on various subjects, notably "Trooper 8008 IY.", ' Practical Licensing Reform," and "The Binding ex the Nile and the New Sadan."
Mr. A. de Goldschmidt Rothsohild leaves Cairo on the Serapis on Snnday.
Mr. W. B. Boom, who has specially chartered Cook's dahabieh Nitocris, left Cairo for the Nile trip on Monday.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo (per the P. & 0. steamer Marmora) is Mr. John Duncan, the well-known newspaper proprietor of Cardiff, and ex chairman of the Press Association of London.

Lient. W. M. Logan-Home, of the 2nd Batt. Royal Snssex Regiment, who embarked at Crete in the P. & 0. S.8.8unda on the 7th inst., for passage to Port8aid, will embark to-morrow iu the transport S.oilia, for oenveyanoe to Karachi.

Lient. W. H. Whyte, jlst Bn. Royal Dublin Fasiliere, has been granted sick leave on the recommendation of a medioal board, until the 17 Jane. He will embark at Port Said on the I8rh inst., in the Anchor Line S.S. Circassian, for Marseilles.

Among the Amerioan toarists coming to Egypt next week is Mr. George Ade, who has engaged a dihxbieh for his trip up the Nile. Mr. Ade is famons in Amerioa as the author of "Fables in Slang," a series of little sketohes in which bits of modern humorous philosophy are conveyed in the anoient form of the fable, bat expressed in the very newest development of the Amerioan vernacular. Mr. Ade'shamonr and philosophy, although distinctively Amerioan, are of universal oarrenoy wherever the Amerioan laDgaage is spoken, but no one has yet been able to translate him into English. Mr. Ade is a successful playwright as well as a specialist in slang, hut none of his plays have a9 yet been seen in England. Though as distinctively Amerioan in idea aud form as the "Fables," they are not so difficult to understand, and one of them may he produoed in London shortly.

Among the visitors staying at the Hotel des Bains, Helouan, are Baron von Maydell, Russia; Baron von Schenk, Cologne; Consul and Mrs. Martens, Sicily*; Deputator and Mrs. A. The interchange of Franco German semi official recriminations wan continued yesterday, bat an Algeciras telegram dated midnight ssya that a real improvement is manifest and that the feeling of uneasiness has disappeared. (R.)
The situation is perceptibly ameliorated. (Havae)
The Chamber has adopted the Franco Russian commercial treaty by 407 to 55. (R.)
The City Liberal Association has decided not to oppose Mr. Balfour. (Reuter,

Mr. Balfour, who was the principal guest at a banquet in honour of the new City member* yesterday evening, reiterated his adherence to a policy of retaliation for the exeoation of which a general tariff was unnecessary, but the question would not be dealt with for some years, aad therefore there was no use in quarrelling over methods so long as the party was united in principle. The duty of the Opposition was to oritioise the Government. (Reut*)

div.head: THE RUSSIAN TROUBLES. DEPORTATION OF WORKMEN.

div.p: Sixty-five workmen councillors here have been deported to Archangel, Tobolsk and YeniKeisk.

The relations between Greece and Roumania, which have I een for a long time estranged, have received a fresh blow by the expulsion from Roamania of a nambsr of well-to-do Greeks belonging to the Hellenismo* Society, which aims at Pan-Hellenism and promotes the agitation in Maoedenia.

div.head: GREEK POLITICS. POSITION OF THE CABINET.

div.p: In the Chamber, the Military deputies have opposed excluding military officers from the Chamber, and indulged in obstruction. M. Theotokis suspended the sitting. Dissolution or resignation of the Cabinet is threatened. (R-uUsr)
The Opposition is obstructing the passage of the Bill excluding military men from the Chamber. M. Theotokis will demand a disso-lution. (Hanat)

div.head: THE BRITISH PARLIAMENT. ELECTION OF SPEAKER.

div.p: Parliament has assembled. Sir Wilfrid Lawson moved and Sir Stuart Wortley seconded the proposal for the re-election of Sir James Low- ther as Speaker, which was agreed to uranimously. Sir Henry Campbell Bannerman in congratulating him, expressed his coofiience that Sir J. Lowther would preserve the House from any encroachment on the part r f any ex ternal authority. Mr. Akers Douglas followed OD behalf of the Opposition. Mr. Keir Hardie emphasised the independence of the Labourites by congraulating him ou their behalf. (Reuter
M. Pallikres has resigned his position a senator. The ejection of the Presiden of th* Senate is fixed for Friday.

THE POSTAL ADMINISTRATION.
To THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—R'garding the new regulation of the Post Offi;e Administration to which you drew attention iu your leader of the 12th inat., itap nears to u=t a most unwarrantable proceeding to wilfully detain letters addressed to well-kn- wu firms, who have been in the habit of receiving letters f ,r many years with no o*her address than "Alexandria" on them, and whose addres ses are perfeotly well known to the postal authorities, and which in must civilised ooun- triea might render the postmaster liable to legal proceedings should loss or damage be oaased through the wilful detention of letters. We ourselves have on several occasions received daring the toarist season whole sackfals of letters for the passengers and orews of steam- mers, hardly any of which have more than "Alexandria" as an address on thsm.the senders naturally concluding that that woald be amply sufficient to find any firm of long standing in Alexandria. The detention of such letters for a day might mean their not reaching the receivers by the time they left Alexandria, and it might he weeks afterwards before they received them, and who can say what inconvenience and loss this might cause to some of the receiver*. Again we are often receiving letters from comparative strangers, some of which it is of the utmost importance should be answered by return of post, and the detention may mean not only actual inooavenienoe, but actnal loss.

We are perfeotly well aware that the difficulty might be got over by having a box at the post office, and sending ourselves for the letters by each mail, but iu the first place we understand all the boxes in the post office are engaged, and secondly we are too far from the post office to intake it easy or convenient for as to send there for oar letter*, which mast be the oase with mary other firms besides oarselves. This is a matt nr of s ch general importance to the commercial communities of Alexandria and Cairo, that we feel con vine ed that it has only to ba brought to the attention of the higher authorities, to have this most arbitrary and unjnstifiab'e rule modified.

W« can quite understand the d ffioulty that the Postal Authorities have in finding the addresses of many private individuals and of firms newly established, and in such cases where the actaal address is not at once known by the post office sorters, they are perfectly right to retain the letters for s post, but in oases where the address are well-known, to deliberately sort out the letters which are not fully addressed and to forward the others, is not only aa absurdity, hut almost amounts to a crime. We beg to remain, Sir, yours faithfully,
P. P. JOHN Ross & Co.
T. DARTON.
Marina, Alexandria, February 13.

div.head: THE ASSOUAN BALL INCIDENT.
To THE EDIT)R OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir,—I quite agree with "a correspondent" in his account of the Assouan fancy dress ball, especially as to the voting for the best costumes. It is a disgrace for any lady to parade before native men servants, eto., in a costume, other than one belonging to her sex, and it is no wonder, that in one of the latest books on Egypt, by a foreigner, remarks, other than complimentary, to female tourisms, should be made. Thus the majority suffer for the foolish minority. I cannot help thinking that the lady (?) who, as your correspondent rightly says, "had the hardihood to black her face and appear as a Cook's dragoman" resembles some of our heroes of antiquity, who, failing to gain notoriety by good deeds, had to resort to anything but laudable ones in order that their names be carried to posterity. That such conduct can encourage Egyptians in the emancipation, or liberty, of their womenkind is very doubtful to—Yours, eto.,
A LOVER OF WOMENLY WOMEN.
Assouan, Febrnary 9.

div.head: EGYPT AND TURKEY.
div.p: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE. HELOUAN SPORTING CLUB. AN ANTICIPATION.

The following official note has boon com'- mnnicated to the Press. Incons- qnenee of certain artioles appearing in the local Pre-s with reference to the Sinai frontier, the Ministry of War informs the public that there are oertaiu differences of op'nion as to the frontier, which has not yet been delimitated. Negotiations are bring carried on in a most amicable spirit, and a friendly settlement will doubtless be effected in the near futnre. A correspondent sends ns the following "jeo d'esprii" from the ' Express" of 1935. We arehapvyto state that the developments he foreshadows are not likely to ensue from the present incident, owing to the prospect of an amicable settlement : — As some of our readers have not had the leisure to follow the history of the numerous boundary disputes between Turkey and Egypt, we give the following short summary otthe successive stages of the negotiations as to the frontier relations between E^ypt and Turkey from 1905 to the present date, which show the slow progress of the frontiers of the 0 toman Empire towards the Suez Canal, which has led to the present strained situation. Had our home politicians only realised, etc. etc. 1905. A Turkish force takes deserters from au Egyptian vessel and constructs storehouses on the Egyptian side of the Tripoli frontier. Egypt being an integral part of the Ottoman dominions no frontier questions can arise between Egypt and the Porte. Negotiations commence. t 1906. Ma'An-Akaba line begun. Turks establish a post at Dabah on the Egyptian ride of the Akaba el Arish line; negotiations continue. 1908. Ma'an Akaba line completed. Turkish garrison at Dab*h trebled. Egyptian protests are met with the deolarat on (see under 1905). Negotiations continue amicably. 1909. The Turkish authorities establish a post between Solum and Kanais. Energetic protests meet with the rrp'y that Egypt etc. 19'0. Akaba fortified, the Turkish forces evaouate Dabah. Negotiations re the Tripoli frontier progress most amicably 1911. The Turks oooupy Dabah el Sugheiyer eight miles N. of the Dabah and on the Egyptian side of the frontier. 1913. A boundary commission from Cairo arrives at Akaba to meet Turkish delegates. Three ot its members arrested for espionage. Representations to Stamboul and the despatch of over 500 telegrams from the Egyptian Foreign Office and the British Ageroy result in the release of the captive dehmitators snd the punishment of a Turkish Ynzbariri. The Boundary commission meets. It being discover-ed that thefTurkish Commission has no powers, the delimitation is postponed. 1914. The Boundary Commissions meet at El Arish and proceed inland, tut return owing to rumours of a Bedouin conspiracy under Sheikhs Abou Dagu and Abu Shenab against the TaTkish party. 1920. The boundary onmmissio''s having at laat completed their labours, the Sublime Porte before signing the frontier treaty demands a rectfioation of the frontier near both Akaba and El Arish. 1921. A Turkish boundary commission leaves Dam* from Solum by land, but owing to a general confusion officially attributed to a standstorm arrives ak. Diamond near Siwa, where it hoists the Tarkifih flag and retarne. 1925. The Turkish Government sends strong military forces into the disputed territories near Akaba and El Arish The Emperor Eitel I. visits Alexandria and Ca'ro."Al Lewa' recommends the ce«sion of the Sinai and Mariout to the Porte. Excrement in E/ypt. 1928. Negotiations reported to be on the eve of a fi'ial settlement. 1930. Negotiations reported to be on the eve of a final settlement. 1933. Tripoli frontier negotiations settled after the despatch of five commissions and 18.000 official telegrams. R»joioings at Sharia El Dawaweeu and Kasr El D mbara. 1935. On the ground of its occupation (by a hundred Z»ptiehs) for 24 years, the Porte refuses to evacuate Dihah and S ighaiyar. Dip'omatio ter sion. FiDst Panzerfanst in the Reiriwtag dilates on German commercial interests in the Sinaitio desert and points out that Turkey having alliel itself with the German Enpire and Austria, a Pomeranian grenadier can travel from Stetriu to Dabah and 8ughaiyar in a 3rd class carriage. Fall in gyptian securities; Turkish army mobilises.

J Byrne (5) by 3 up and 2 to play. STROKE COMPETITION. WINNER : J H. Percival with 99 less 8=9 L FOOTBALL. VICTORI \ COLLEGE F. C. u ST. ANDREW F. C. These teams met on the College ground on Saturday afternoon, before a large turn-oat of spectators. Lark started the game for the vi-itors.The College team quickly settled down, and for about ten minntes kept the Saints defending. Cowie initiated the first run into the homest* r's end, but he was indifferently sup-ported and the ball was put pas'-. Saiuts main-tained the pressure fora while, but the home deforce was not to be beaten Yaghen ► hewed to advantage in a rnn in on Cnrtis, but the latter savtd smart'y. Just on the call of half-time Curtis cleverly cleared a oross shot from the righ*-, but before the whistle sounded Abou-el-Ezz h-d the ball past biro aDd the College stood one ap at half-tim*. The point Wes well deserved. The College commerced the second halt strongly and the Saints' defence h*d a lot to do. It was some time before the Saints could break away. The forwards seemed at no time during the game to get proper control of the bnll, and their movements in conseqneno" wire sadly lacking in combination. Jones tried hard to « qnalise, but bis efforts were fruitless. Cowie, who had ( hanged to centre half position, was Paying a sound game and snpported the for wards well Kei;l and Hopkins had a lot of hard work but thiR they accomplished well. Corti# wa« te^eH a lot. but wa# in,»»fe -form between the Time arrived with the score unchanged, leaving the College team viotors by one goal to nil. The Viotoria front line was full of running. Yaghen was the smartest forward on the field, and bounced along full of vitality. Mastard was the most prominent man in the defenoe. He was always ready in .intercepting every pass which was not mathematically aoonrate, and got his head on the ball whenever it rose to any reasonable attitnde, and made judicious and well-timed passes to the men in front of him. He was a host in himself. The Saints' backs were also very safe. Keill's recovery work was good, and Hopkins was always to the re-cue whenever the home forwards were getting too close to Curtis. The College oustodian was not overburdened with work, but was ever ready when called upon. The game was thoroughly enjoyable through-out, and ths College te*m deserved the viotory. The teams wore as follows:—
VICTORIA COLLEGE F.C. F. Saba,' A. Mas tard, A. Verny, A. Nnhas, A. G. Lias G. Valassopoulo. M. Abou-el-Ezz, A. E. Aubrey, A. Morrison, F. G. Lowiok, and M. Saleh Yaghen.
ST. ANDREW F.C.: — Curtis, Hopkins, Keill, Ecclestone, Cowie, Bright, Constantinidis, Rofe, Lark, Jones, and Tulloch. REFEREE : Mr. P. J. Byrne.

div.head: AMATEUR ATHLETIC CLUB.
div.p: The annual athletic meeting of the Alexan-dria Amateur Athletic Club has been fixed for Wednesday, April 4. Intending members of the Club should send in their names to the Hon. Secretary Mr. R. B. MoClean, accompanied by the names of proposer and seconder, who should be members of the Club.

div.head: THE NATIVE PRESS.
div.p: Emigration to tho Sadan. "Ai Lew*" ia a leading article remarks: ''Emigration is very useful and advisable, and it was approved by the Prophet, who emi-grated from Mecca to Medina, 1,323 years ago when the Hegira's date began. To emigrate from one country to another is, for people.to leave their homes seeking fortune, prosperity and better IHe in another country; aud the Sudan can hardly be the land to give prosperity and happiness to the Egyptians at present. Our people will have no privileges in the country which cost us too dearly, but will be there like the Italians and Greeks, who paid no money and sacrificed no lives to restore the Sadan. This is not, therefore, the proper time for our countrymen to emigrate to the Sadan. We must first dema- d our rights in that land and secure our i-hare and privileges. The Sadan is a very large country which will not be filled up by emigrants in a shore time. The area ot Kurd >f an Moudirien alone equals that of France, which is inhabited by 40 millions of population. Therefore the Egyptians would not be losing an opportunity if they remain, for the time being, at home, until their rights in the Sudan are quite secured. The time will come when the sons of the valley of the Nile will gladly emi-grate to thpir second land". The New Sudan Railway. "Al Ahram" publishe* a letter from a native of Cairo to the following »ffeot : — The native press, owing to the opening of the Nde-Red Sea railway, has been dealing for the last few days with the Sudanese question, keenly b'aming the Egyptian Government and severely criticising its policy in sending no offioial representatives to attend the ceremonial inauguration. The absence of Government men on such an important ceremony has indeed caused a sensational exo'tement among the natiVhs, who consider now that Egypt will shortly be deprived of its share in the Sudan. as its influence was suppressed. Now every patriot should ask what should the Government cour-e be in regard to the Sudan ; should E?y 't sustain the loss, while England avails itself by the benefits, or what, we should like to kDOw 1 Can E ypt see its way to get in the future some pnfrs out of the Sudan when the State is, as we see, turned against Egypt's interests ? What answer would our ministries give, if the times were ohanged and they were asked to give an aocoant of the work they had performed in Egypt, and about their unsatis- Lotory aot which put Egypt to a great los* ? What answer conld they make if they were to be rsked about their ignoring the Saltan's firman granted to the Khedive, which contained the following paragraph : ' As the privileges allowed to Egypt are a part of the natnral right of our power, the Khedivial Government has to keep all these privileges very carefully, and must not in way alter all or any of them, or allow a plot of Egyptian land to pass into the hands r f any other Power." Egypt has lost Massawa and is about to lose the Sudan, and has disposed of the Ottoman privileges by concluding an agieement with the British Government on the 19th January, 1899. withoat the oonsent of the Sublime Porte". During the recent visit of the British Asso-ciation to South Afrioa, two trains were provided by the Natal Government Railway for'heir accommodation. It is interesting to note that these trains were equipped throughout with Stone's Patent Eleotrio Light System, and that althongh the trains w^re in use for five weeks, going right up to the Zambesi, this system required no repairs or attention of any kind, and worked excellently bronghont. It is well known that no tronble is to be expected undei ordinary conditions, but that the abnormal requirements of such a tonr a9 that mentioned above should also be met, is a fact which n u t be very gratifying *o all those v«an corned

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: . Captain G. 0. B'gge, Royal Enginesrs, on r-3t'ming home from Cairo, has been postfd to the Eastern District at Co'ohester. He ia ' the senior captain of the Royal Engineers. To-day the S. S. Sicilia left Southampton with over 1,009 troops on board, principally for battalions in the Panjab. The liner is due at Port 8aid on the 15th inst, and at Karaohi on the 26 h following. Captain P. M. Dove, 2nd Battalion Notts aDd Derby Regiment, and Lieutenant C. W. E. Gordon, Royal Highlanders, have been seleoted for service with the Khedive's army. Captain C. K. Morgan, Royal Army Medical Corps, serving in Egypt, has been promoted major, a grade he has reaohed after less than twelve years' service. He got his first commis-sion in July, 1894. Brevet Colonel S. G. Bird, D.S.0.,will vacate the command of the 1st Battalion Royal Dublin Fariliers in Eyypt, in a few months—in June, to ba accurate—under the f mr years' rule. A more popular C.O. never rode' at tha head of tha old ''Lambs." lu the usu 4 oourse Brevet-Lieu tenant Colonel A. W. Gordon, of the 2nd Battalion in Ireland, should get the command. Under the schema for the reorganisation of the Royal E g n«ers, it is i >tendel to introduce a change of considerable imoortance. Hitherto there has been no cohesion between the units told off specially as field companies. This is held to be a defective arrangement, and steps are, therefore to fee taken to form the*e into battalion for service in war. The fortress units created by the abolition of the submarine min-ing companies, will, it is believed, be similarly treated. 4 A smart yoang non-commissioned officer of the S mth Lancashire Regiment, Corporal W.A. Douglas, his just been given a second lieuten-ancy in the R vyal Inuiskilling Fusiliers. Mr. Douglas will join the 1st Battalion at Belfast in the first instance. The coming concentration of sixty battleships and a'moured oruisers of the Atlantic, Mediterranean and Channel Fleets at L*goa Bay, will aff »rd another instance of the mighty naval power of Great Britain. It will be an unmistakable proof that the premier naval power is one in being and not one on paper. Yet it is only a preliminary to the great demonstration of the coming summer, when 340 battleships, cruisers, and smaller ships, will share in the manoeuvres. The lessons of the late struggle in the Far East will fiad a place in the programme, which a9 already stated in these notes, will thoroughly test the present distribution of the naval forces of our Empire both at home and abroad. The British Fleet, independent of its primary duty, the defence of our country, is au important factor in the peace of the world, bat if it were backed up by au army, raised to the standard laid down by Lord Roberts, the position would be still more satisfactory. If any other Continental power had a navy of the same description, it would be a standing menace to peace, instead of being one of thebeit guarantees of it

div.head: CUBAN MINISTER L. S. Recommends Pe-ru-na.
div.p: Senor' Quesada, Cuban Minister io the United States. Senor Quesada, Cuban Minister to the United States, is an orator born. In an article in Tho Outlook for July, 1899, by George Kennan, who heard Quesada speak at the Esteban Theater, Mantanzaa, Cuba, he said: "I have seen many audiences under the spell of eloquent speech and in tho grip of strong emotional excitement; but I have rarely witnessed such a scene as at the close of Quesada's eulogy upon the dead patriot, Marti." In a letter to The Peruna Medicine Company, written from Washington, D. C., Senor Quesada says: "Peruna I can recommend as a very good medi-cine. It is an excellent strengthening tonic, and it is also an efficacious cure for the almost universal complaint of catarrh. "---Gonzalo De Quesada Congressman J. H. Bankhead, of Ala-bama, one of the most Influential members of the House of Representatives, in a letter written from Washington, Da C., gives his endorsement to the great catarrh remedy, Peruna, in the following words: "Your Peruna la one of the beat medicines I ever tried, and no fadiUy should ba without your remarkable remedy. Aa a tonic and catarrh cure I know ot nothing better."—J. H. Bankhead. There is but a single medicine Which is a radical specific for catarrh. It is Peruna, which has stood a half century test and cured thousands of cases. Peruna is for sale by all chemists and druggists at five shil lings per bottle or six bottles for twenty-five shillings. div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.
